channel.title: OpenDNS
channel.description: Anyone here use it? My ISP's nameserver fell over yesterday, so browsing the web was difficult, switched to OpenDNS and my internet has become noticeably quicker.

item.title: OpenDNS
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The IP 208.69.36.132 has never changed for me since I started using dnsmasq like this in November I believe, but you can add more than 1 IP.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenDNS
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:14, topic:304301”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=400592.msg3127371#msg3127371 date=1266129042]

Google’s (8.8.4.4, 8.8.8.8) is easier to remember and a lot better, no OpenDNS search results or any other crap

Instead of OpenDNS search results you get google search results instead right? Same difference.

Or you can use dnsmasq as a caching DNS server for your home network, configure it to use opendns, and tell it to serve nxdomain instead of opendns’s search page when a domain doesn’t exist. That’s the best of all worlds.

how exactly do you do that? thats exactly what ive been trying to do, to no avail
[/quote]

This is for opendns:

[quote=dnsmasq.conf]# If you want dnsmasq to detect attempts by Verisign to send queries

to unregistered .com and .net hosts to its sitefinder service and

have dnsmasq instead return the correct NXDOMAIN response, uncomment

this line. You can add similar lines to do the same for other

registries which have implemented wildcard A records.

bogus-nxdomain=208.69.36.132[/quote]

So now the query works as follows:

[code]$ nslookup domainthatdoesntexist.com
Server: 192.168.1.3
Address: 192.168.1.3#53

** server can’t find domainthatdoesntexist.com: NXDOMAIN
[/code]

Instead of doing the opendns search thing. :)[/quote]
the ip keeps changing, but im just using the firefox addon now so its fine

Read full topic

item.title: OpenDNS
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:13, topic:304301”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=400592.msg3127345#msg3127345 date=1266125755]

Google’s (8.8.4.4, 8.8.8.8) is easier to remember and a lot better, no OpenDNS search results or any other crap

Instead of OpenDNS search results you get google search results instead right? Same difference.

Or you can use dnsmasq as a caching DNS server for your home network, configure it to use opendns, and tell it to serve nxdomain instead of opendns’s search page when a domain doesn’t exist. That’s the best of all worlds.
[/quote]
how exactly do you do that? thats exactly what ive been trying to do, to no avail[/quote]

This is for opendns:

# If you want dnsmasq to detect attempts by Verisign to send queries # to unregistered .com and .net hosts to its sitefinder service and # have dnsmasq instead return the correct NXDOMAIN response, uncomment # this line. You can add similar lines to do the same for other # registries which have implemented wildcard A records. bogus-nxdomain=208.69.36.132

So now the query works as follows:

[code]$ nslookup domainthatdoesntexist.com
Server: 192.168.1.3
Address: 192.168.1.3#53

** server can’t find domainthatdoesntexist.com: NXDOMAIN
[/code]

Instead of doing the opendns search thing.

Read full topic

[/quote]

Instead of OpenDNS search results you get google search results instead right? Same difference.

Or you can use dnsmasq as a caching DNS server for your home network, configure it to use opendns, and tell it to serve nxdomain instead of opendns’s search page when a domain doesn’t exist. That’s the best of all worlds.[/quote]
how exactly do you do that? thats exactly what ive been trying to do, to no avail

item.title: OpenDNS
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

chri5:

Google’s (8.8.4.4, 8.8.8.8) is easier to remember and a lot better, no OpenDNS search results or any other crap

Instead of OpenDNS search results you get google search results instead right? Same difference.

Or you can use dnsmasq as a caching DNS server for your home network, configure it to use opendns, and tell it to serve nxdomain instead of opendns’s search page when a domain doesn’t exist. That’s the best of all worlds.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenDNS
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

I have configured my router to use OpenDNS rather than my ISP’s DNS server, as my ISP’s DNS server tends to be down a lot, which is a bitch.
OpenDNS is always working however, and provides me with some neat features.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenDNS
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I actually use it and love it, and it does make DNS lookups faster not only because they have fast servers, but because since so many thousands or millions of people use them, the answer you are looking for is almost always cached so that it can be returned to you immediately instead of finding the main servers and getting an answer from them. Additionally you will have the latest, up to date DNS information because unlike some ISP’s DNS servers who keep records past their TTL, OpenDNS will not do that and even allows domain owners such as myself to refresh certain records whenever we want to, even before the TTL.

I like OpenDNS.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenDNS
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

I used to think I was smart by using OpenDNS too.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenDNS
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Cowie`:

ur an idiet.

Agree. Switching DNS servers doesn’t ‘speed up your connection’, it just can speed up the lookup time. But, this is usually only by a few milliseconds (possibly less).

Read full topic
